satlas2.core module#

Implementation of the base Fitter, Source, Model and Parameter classes

evaluateOverWalk(filename: str, burnin: int = 0, x: ArrayLike = None, evals: int = 0) → Tuple[list, list][source]#

The parameters saved in the h5 file are evaluated in the models a specific number of times. From these evaluations, the 16, 50 and 84 percentiles (corresponding to the 1-sigma band) are calculated.

Parameters

  • filename (str) â€“ Filename of the random walk results.

  • burnin (int, optional) â€“ Amount of steps to skip, by default 0

  • x (ArrayLike, optional) â€“ Evaluation points for the model, defaults to the datapoints in Source

  • evals (int, optional) â€“ Number of selected parameter values, defaults to using all values

Returns

A tuple with, as the first element, a list of arrays x-values for which the band has been evaluated. Each source contributes an array. The second element is a list of 2D arrays, one for each source. The first row is the sigma- boundary, the second row is the median value and the third row is the sigm+ boundary.

Return type

Tuple of lists

fit(llh: bool = False, llh_method: str = 'gaussian', method: str = 'leastsq', mcmc_kwargs: dict = {}, sampler_kwargs: dict = {}, filename: Optional[str] = None, steps: int = 1000, nwalkers: int = 50, scale_covar: bool = True, iter_cb: Optional[callable] = None) → None[source]#

Perform a fit of the models (added to the sources) to the data in the sources. Models in the same source are summed together, models in different sources can be linked through their parameters.

Parameters

  • llh (bool, optional) â€“ Selects if a chisquare (False) or likelihood fit is performed, by default False.

  • llh_method (str, optional) â€“ Selects which likelihood calculation is used, by default â€˜gaussianâ€™.

  • method (str, optional) â€“ Selects the method used by the lmfit.minimizer(), by default â€˜leastsqâ€™. Set to â€˜emceeâ€™ for random walk.

  • mcmc_kwargs (dict, optional) â€“ Dictionary of keyword arguments to be supplied to the MCMC routine (see emcee.EnsembleSampler.sample()), by default {}

  • sampler_kwargs (dict, optional) â€“ Dictionary of keyword arguments to be supplied to the emcee.EnsembleSampler() , by default {}

  • filename (str, optional) â€“ Filename in which the random walk should be saved, by default None

  • steps (int, optional) â€“ Number of steps the random walk should, by default 1000

  • nwalkers (int, optional) â€“ Number of walkers to be used in the random walk, by default 50

  • scale_covar (bool, optional) â€“ Scale the calculated uncertainties by the root of the reduced chisquare, by default True. Set to False when llh is True, since the reduced chisquare calculated in this case is not applicable.

readWalk(filename: str, burnin: int = 0)[source]#

Read and process the h5 file containing the results of a random walk. The parameter values and uncertainties are extracted from the walk.

Parameters

filename (str) â€“ Filename of the random walk results.

reportFit(modelpars: Optional[Parameters] = None, show_correl: bool = False, min_correl: float = 0.1, sort_pars: Union[bool, callable] = False) → str[source]#

Generate a report of the fitting results.

The report contains the best-fit values for the parameters and their uncertainties and correlations.

Parameters

  • modelpars (lmfit.Parameters, optional) â€“ Known Model Parameters

  • show_correl (bool, optional) â€“ Whether to show a list of sorted correlations, by default False

  • min_correl (float, optional) â€“ Smallest correlation in absolute value to show, by default 0.1

  • sort_pars (bool or callable, optional) â€“ Whether to show parameter names sorted in alphanumerical order. If False (default), then the parameters will be listed in the order they were added to the Parameters dictionary. If callable, then this (one argument) function is used to extract a comparison key from each list element.

Returns

Multi-line text of fit report.

Return type

str

revertFit()[source]#

Reverts the parameter values to the original values.

setExpr(parameter_name: Union[list, str], parameter_expression: Union[list, str]) → None[source]#

Set the expression to be used for the given parameters. The given parameter names should be the full description i.e. containing the source and model name.

Note

The priority order on expressions is

  1. Expressions given by setExpr()

  2. Sharing of parameters through shareParams()

  3. Sharing of parameters through shareModelParams()

Parameters

  • parameter_name (list or str) â€“ Either a single parameter name or a list of them.

  • parameter_expression (list or str) â€“ The parameter expression to be associated with parameter_name.

setParamPrior(source: str, model: str, parameter_name: str, value: float, uncertainty: float) → None[source]#

Set a Gaussian prior on a parameter, mainly intended to represent literature values.

Parameters

  • source (str) â€“ Name of the datasource in which the parameter is present.

  • model (str) â€“ Name of the model in which the parameter is present.

  • parameter_name (str) â€“ Name of the parameter.

  • value (float) â€“ Central value of the Gaussian

  • uncertainty (float) â€“ Standard deviation associated with the value.

shareModelParams(parameter_name: Union[list, str]) → None[source]#

Add parameters to the list of shared parameters across all models with the same name.

Note

The priority order on expressions is

  1. Expressions given by setExpr()

  2. Sharing of parameters through shareParams()

  3. Sharing of parameters through shareModelParams()

Parameters

parameter_name (list or str) â€“ List of parameters or single parameter name.

shareParams(parameter_name: Union[list, str]) → None[source]#

Add parameters to the list of shared parameters.

Note

The full parameter name should be given.

Note

The priority order on expressions is

  1. Expressions given by setExpr()

  2. Sharing of parameters through shareParams()

  3. Sharing of parameters through shareModelParams()

Parameters

parameter_name (list or str) â€“ List of parameters or single parameter name.

satlas2.interface module#

Implementation of the base HFSModel and SumModel classes, based on the syntax used in the original satlas

NOTE: THIS IS NOT FULLY BENCHMARKED/DEVELOPED SO BUGS MIGHT BE PRESENT, AND NOT ALL FUNCTIONALITIES OF THE ORIGINAL SATLAS ARE IMPLEMENTED

class satlas2.interface.HFSModel(I: float, J: ArrayLike[float, float], ABC: ArrayLike[float, float, float, float, float, float], centroid: float = 0, fwhm: ArrayLike[float, float] = [50.0, 50.0], scale: float = 1.0, background_params: ArrayLike = [0.001], shape: str = 'voigt', use_racah: bool = True, use_saturation: bool = False, saturation: float = 0.001, sidepeak_params: dict = {'N': None, 'Offset': 0, 'Poisson': 0}, crystalballparams=None, pseudovoigtparams=None, asymmetryparams=None, name: str = 'HFModel__')[source]#

Bases: object

Initializes a hyperfine spectrum Model with the given hyperfine parameters.

Parameters

  • I (float) â€“ Integer or half-integer value of the nuclear spin

  • J (ArrayLike) â€“ A sequence of 2 spins, respectively the J value of the lower state and the J value of the higher state

  • ABC (ArrayLike) â€“ A sequence of 2 A, 2 B and 2 C values, respectively for the lower and the higher state

  • centroid (float, optional) â€“ The centroid of the spectrum, by default 0

  • fwhm (ArrayLike, length = 2, optional) â€“ First element: The Gaussian FWHM of the Voigt profile, by default 50 Second element: The Lorentzian FWHM of the Voigt profile, by default 50

  • scale (float, optional) â€“ The amplitude of the entire spectrum, by default 1.0

  • background_params (ArrayLike, optional) â€“ The coefficients of the polynomial background, by default [0.001]

  • shape (str, optional) â€“ Voigt only

  • use_racah (bool, optional) â€“ Use individual amplitudes are setting the Racah intensities, by default True

  • use_saturation (bool, optional) â€“ False only

  • saturation (float, optional) â€“ No saturation

  • sidepeak_params (dict, optional) â€“ keys:

  • N (int, optional) â€“ Number of sidepeaks to be generated, by default None

  • Poisson (float, optional) â€“ The poisson factor for the sidepeaks, by default 0

  • Offset (float, optional) â€“ Offset in units of x for the sidepeak, by default 0

  • prefunc (callable, optional) â€“ Transformation to be applied on the input before evaluation, by default None

chisquare_fit(x: ArrayLike, y: ArrayLike, yerr: Union[ArrayLike, callable] = None, xerr: ArrayLike = None, func: callable = None, verbose: bool = False, hessian: bool = False, method: str = 'leastsq', show_correl: bool = True) → Tuple[bool, str][source]#

Perform a fit of this model to the data provided in this function.

Parameters

  • x (ArrayLike) â€“ x-values of the data points

  • y (ArrayLike) â€“ y-values of the data-points

  • yerr (Union[ArrayLike, callable], optional) â€“ 1-sigma error on the y-values, values or function to be used on f(x), by default None=sqrt(f(x))

  • xerr (ArrayLike, optional) â€“ 1-sigma error on the x-values, by default None

  • func (callable, optional) â€“ Not implemented

  • verbose (bool, optional) â€“ Not implemented, by default False

  • hessian (bool, optional) â€“ Not implemented, by default False

  • method (str, optional) â€“ Selects the method used by the lmfit.minimizer(), by default â€˜leastsqâ€™

Returns

Returns a boolean indicating the success of the fit, and the message accompanying it.

Return type

Tuple[bool, str]

Raises

NotImplementedError â€“ When the chosen options for func, verbose and Hessian result is not implemented.

get_result(selection: str = 'chisquare') → Tuple[list, list, list][source]#

Return the variable names, values and estimated error bars for the parameters as seperate lists.

Parameters

selection (string, optional) â€“ Selects if the chisquare (â€˜chisquareâ€™ or â€˜anyâ€™) or MLE values are used. Defaults to â€˜chisquareâ€™, and chisquare only

Returns

names, values, uncertainties â€“ Returns a 3-tuple of lists containing the names of the parameters, the values and the estimated uncertainties, scaled with the reduced chisquared.

Return type

tuple of lists

get_result_dict(method: str = 'chisquare', scaled: bool = True) → dict[source]#

Returns the fitted parameters in a dictionary of the form {name: [value, uncertainty]}.

Parameters

  • method ({'chisquare', 'mle'}) â€“ Selects which parameters have to be returned, by default â€˜chisquareâ€™, and only â€˜chisquareâ€™

  • scaled (boolean) â€“ Selects if, in case of chisquare parameters, the uncertainty has to be scaled by sqrt(reduced_chisquare). Defaults to True, and only True

Returns

Dictionary of the form described above.

Return type

dict

get_result_frame(method: str = 'chisquare', selected: bool = False, bounds: bool = False, vary: bool = False, scaled: bool = True) → DataFrame[source]#

Returns the data from the fit in a pandas DataFrame.

Parameters

  • method (str, optional) â€“ Selects which fitresults have to be loaded. Can be â€˜chisquareâ€™ or â€˜mleâ€™. Defaults to â€˜chisquareâ€™, and only â€˜chisquareâ€™.

  • selected (list of strings, optional) â€“ Selects the parameters that have any string in the list as a substring in their name. Set to None to select all parameters. Defaults to None, and only None.

  • bounds (boolean, optional) â€“ Selects if the boundary also has to be given. Defaults to False, and onlyb False.

  • vary (boolean, optional) â€“ Selects if only the parameters that have been varied have to be supplied. Defaults to False, and only False.

  • scaled (boolean, optional) â€“ Sets the uncertainty scaling with the reduced chisquare value. Default to True, and only True

Returns

resultframe â€“ Dateframe with MultiIndex, using the variable names as main column names and the two rows under for the value and the uncertainty

Return type

DataFrame

set_expr(constraints: dict) → None[source]#

Set the expression to be used for the given parameters. The constraint should be a dict with following structure:

key: string

Parameter to constrain

value: ArrayLike, length = 2

First element: Factor to multiply Second element: Parameter that the key should be constrained to. {â€˜Auâ€™:[â€˜0.5â€™,â€™Alâ€™]} results in Au = 0.5*Al

set_variation(varyDict: dict) → None[source]#

Sets the variation of the fitparameters as supplied in the dictionary.

Parameters

varyDict (dictionary) â€“ A dictionary containing â€˜key: True/Falseâ€™ mappings with the parameter names as keys.

class satlas2.interface.SumModel(models: list, background_params: list, name: str = 'sum', source_name: str = 'source')[source]#

Bases: object

Initializes a hyperfine spectrum for the sum of multiple Models with the given models and a step background.

Parameters

  • models (ArrayLike, with instances of HFSModel as elements) â€“ The models that should be summed

  • background_params (Dict with keys: 'values' and 'bounds' and values ArrayLike) â€“ The bounds where the background changes stepwise in key â€˜boundsâ€™ The background values between the bounds i.e. {â€˜valuesâ€™: [2,5], â€˜boundsâ€™:[-10]} means a background of 2 from -inf to -10, and a background of 5 from -10 to +inf

  • name (string, optional) â€“ Name of this summodel

  • source_name (string, optional) â€“ Name of the DataSource instance (from satlas2)

chisquare_fit(x: ArrayLike, y: ArrayLike, yerr: Union[ArrayLike, callable] = None, xerr: ArrayLike = None, func: callable = None, verbose: bool = False, hessian: bool = False, method: str = 'leastsq') → Tuple[bool, str][source]#

get_result(selection: str = 'chisquare') → Tuple[list, list, list][source]#

Return the variable names, values and estimated error bars for the parameters as seperate lists.

Parameters

selection (string, optional) â€“ Selects if the chisquare (â€˜chisquareâ€™ or â€˜anyâ€™) or MLE values are used. Defaults to â€˜chisquareâ€™, and chisquare only

Returns

names, values, uncertainties â€“ Returns a 3-tuple of lists containing the names of the parameters. The first list each tuple element contains the names/values/uncertainties of the first model added to the summodel, etc. The last list in each tuple element contains the names/values/uncertainties for the step background The values and the estimated uncertainties are always scaled with the reduced chisquared.

Return type

tuple of lists

get_result_dict(method: str = 'chisquare', scaled: bool = True) → dict[source]#

Returns the fitted parameters in a dictionary of the form {name of model in summodel : {name: [value, uncertainty]}}. Background values are under key â€˜bkgâ€™ in dictionary.

Parameters

  • method ({'chisquare', 'mle'}) â€“ Selects which parameters have to be returned, by default â€˜chisquareâ€™, and only â€˜chisquareâ€™

  • scaled (boolean) â€“ Selects if, in case of chisquare parameters, the uncertainty has to be scaled by sqrt(reduced_chisquare). Defaults to True, and only True

Returns

Dictionary of the form described above.

Return type

dict

Returns the data from the fit in a pandas DataFrame.

  • selected (list of strings, optional) â€“ Selects the parameters that have any string in the list as a substring in their name. Set to None to select all parameters. Defaults to None, and only None.

  • bounds (boolean, optional) â€“ Selects if the boundary also has to be given. Defaults to False, and onlyb False.

  • vary (boolean, optional) â€“ Selects if only the parameters that have been varied have to be supplied. Defaults to False, and only False.

  • scaled (boolean, optional) â€“ Sets the uncertainty scaling with the reduced chisquare value. Default to True, and only True

satlas2.plotting module#

Functions for the generation of plots related to the fitting results.

satlas2.plotting.generateChisquareMap(fitter, filter=None, method='chisquare', resolution_diag=15, resolution_map=15, fit_kws={}, source=False, model=True)[source]#

Generates a correlation map for either the chisquare or the MLE method. On the diagonal, the chisquare or loglikelihood is drawn as a function of one fixed parameter. Refitting to the data each time gives the points on the line. A dashed line is drawn on these plots, with the intersection with the plots giving the correct confidence interval for the parameter. In solid lines, the interval estimated by the fitting routine is drawn. On the offdiagonal, two parameters are fixed and the model is again fitted to the data. The change in chisquare/loglikelihood is mapped to 1, 2 and 3 sigma contourmaps.

Parameters

  • fitter (Fitter) â€“ Fitter instance for which the chisquare map must be created.

  • filter (list of strings) â€“ Only the parameters matching the names given in this list will be used to generate the maps.

  • resolution_diag (int) â€“ Number of points for the line plot on each diagonal.

  • resolution_map (int) â€“ Number of points along each dimension for the meshgrids.

  • fit_kws (dictionary) â€“ Dictionary of keywords to pass on to the fitting routine.

  • npar (int) â€“ Number of parameters for which simultaneous predictions need to be made. Influences the uncertainty estimates from the parabola.

satlas2.plotting.generateCorrelationPlot(filename, filter=None, bins=None, burnin=0, source=True, binreduction=1, bin2dreduction=1, model=True)[source]#

Given the random walk data, creates a triangle plot: distribution of a single parameter on the diagonal axes, 2D contour plots with 1, 2 and 3 sigma contours on the off-diagonal. The 1-sigma limits based on the percentile method are also indicated, as well as added to the title.

Parameters

  • filename (string) â€“ Filename for the h5 file containing the data from the walk.

  • filter (list of str, optional) â€“ If supplied, only this list of columns is used for the plot.

  • bins (int or list of int, optional) â€“ If supplied, use this number of bins for the plotting.

Returns

Returns the MatPlotLib figure created.

Return type

figure

satlas2.plotting.generateWalkPlot(filename, filter=None, burnin=0, source=False, model=True)[source]#

Given the random walk data, the random walk for the selected parameters is plotted.

Parameters

  • filename (string) â€“ Filename for the h5 file containing the data from the walk.

  • filter (list of str, optional) â€“ If supplied, only this list of parameters is used for the plot.

Returns

Returns the MatPlotLib figure created.

Return type

figure
